  "ok": true,
  "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/live-story/news/world/2026/02/23/mexico-el-mencho-live-updates-news/88821399007/",
  "final_url": "https://www.usatoday.com/live-story/news/world/2026/02/23/mexico-el-mencho-live-updates-news/88821399007/",
  "status_code": 200,
  "title": "'El Mencho' death sparks unrest, security risks in Mexico",
  "content": "'El Mencho' death sparks unrest, security risks in Mexico Find us on Google üìå Eating like it is 1776 Start the day smarter ‚òÄÔ∏è Get the USA TODAY app U.S. Politics Sports Entertainment Life Money Travel Opinion Crossword ONLY AT USA TODAY: Newsletters For Subscribers Real Estate From the Archives USA TODAY PLAY Crossword eNewspaper Magazines Investigations Video Podcasts Humankind WITNESS (True Crime) California Atlanta Just Curious Best-selling Booklist Top Workplaces Nomination Legals Press Releases Cars Grocery Shopping OUR PORTFOLIO: Real Estate 10BEST USAT Savings Shopping Blueprint WITNESS (True Crime) Southern Kitchen Home Internet Services WORLD Mexico Add Topic Mexico grapples with unrest, security risks after 'El Mencho' killed Kathryn Palmer Lauren Villagran USA TODAY Updated Feb. 23, 2026, 8:12 p.m. ET Locals and tourists took shelter across Mexico amid a wave of retaliatory violence after government forces killed a powerful cartel leader , with gunmen blocking highways and torching cars. The death of Nemesio RubeÃÅn Oseguera Cervantes , commonly known as \"El Mencho,\" announced Sunday, Feb. 23, triggered \"27 cowardly attacks against authorities in Jalisco,\" Mexican Security Minister Omar Garcia Harfuch told reporters on Monday, adding that 30 cartel operatives were killed as well as one bystander. At least 70 people were arrested in seven states. The U.S. State Department on Feb. 23 widened a security warning advising Americans in several Mexican states to \"shelter in place\" until further notice, as Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo said \"tranquility\" had been restored and President Donald Trump urged her government to \"step up their effort on Cartels and Drugs!\" The State Department later, relaxed its warning for certain areas. 'El Mencho' killed in Mexico: Who was the notorious cartel leader? President Trump urged the Mexican government to \"step up their effort on Cartels and Drugs!\" after Nemesio RubeÃÅn Oseguera Cervantes, known as \"El Mencho,\" was killed on Sunday. Mexico's president said cartel roadblocks had been cleared from Mexico's highways and that flights would resume in a few days. The State Department says it had \"fielded hundreds of calls\" from travelers in Mexico with \"most pertaining to flight cancellations.\" 7:33 pm ET February 23, 2026 Share this update Is it safe to travel to Mexico right now? Eve Chen Travelers with imminent plans to vacation in Mexico may want to pause, Mike Ballard, director of intelligence at security firm Global Guardian, told USA TODAY. While resort areas and hotels have been \"relatively spared from the impact,\" he said, people should reconsider their travel plans to Puerto Vallarta or Cancun in the next 48 hours. \"We don‚Äôt know exactly how this is going to continue to play out. It could get worse, it could get better,\" Ballard said. Jason Hanson, former CIA officer and author of ‚ÄúSpy Secrets That Can Save Your Life,‚Äù put it more bluntly: ‚ÄúDo not go to Mexico.‚Äù ‚ÄúI do a lot of security consulting, a lot of travel, and I‚Äôve told people this for the last decade: Do not go to Mexico,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt is way too volatile, way too dangerous. ‚Ä¶ Your life is too precious. Your security‚Äôs too precious. There‚Äôs a million other beautiful places in this world.‚Äù 7:11 pm ET February 23, 2026 Share this update Violence in Mexico could last for days Josh Meyer The public display of violence in Mexico following the slaying of drug lord Nemesio RubeÃÅn Oseguera Cervantes could continue for a few days or weeks, given his stature within the Jalisco New Generation Cartel and the group's extraordinary military-style capabilities, veteran cartel watchers tell USA TODAY. The cartel produced a similar nationwide show of force in 2015, even using a rocket-propelled grenade to shoot down a Mexican army helicopter, after the Mexican military tried to capture Oseguera Cervantes, more commonly known as \"El Mencho.\" ‚ÄúIf past is prologue, what we've seen is that there will be at least a week, maybe more, of these sort of violent reprisals by the cartels. And then things will turn inward,‚Äù Anthony Placido, former head of intelligence for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, told USA TODAY. 6:50 pm ET February 23, 2026 Share this update Mexico deploys 2,000 additional troops to region Michael Loria Authorities in Mexico on Monday deployed an additional 2,000 soldiers to the western part of Jalisco, the Mexican state where most of the fighting is happening. Contributing by Reuters 6:01 pm ET February 23, 2026 Share this update Most airports in Mexico return to normal operations Francesca Chambers Most airports in Mexico are now operating normally, the State Department said on Monday evening as it narrowed its shelter in place advisory for U.S. citizens. U.S. citizens in Puerto Vallarta and the surrounding areas in Jalisco and Nayarit are still being encouraged to shelter in place \"due to road blockages and criminal activity related\" to the Mexican military raid on Feb. 22. However, the State Department said multiple airlines were operating from Guadalajara and from Puerto Vallarta as of this afternoon. \"Confirm that your flight is on track for departure from Guadalajara or Puerto Vallarta before you depart for the airport,\" it said. 5:37 pm ET February 23, 2026 Share this update US government fields 'hundreds' of calls from stranded travelers Francesca Chambers The State Department says it \"has fielded hundreds of calls\" from travelers in Mexico with \"most pertaining to flight cancellations.\" The call center is operating 24/7, the State Department said. Americans traveling abroad who need assistance can call +1-202-501-4444 from outside the United States or dial +1-888-407-4747 from the United States or Canada. The U.S. government is also encouraging Americans traveling abroad to enroll in the Smart Traveler Enrollment Program to receive updates about health, weather, safety, and security at their destinations. They can also follow the ‚ÄúU.S. Department of State ‚Äì",
  "truncated": true,
  "content_length": 23238
}

The death of Nemesio RubeÃÅn Oseguera Cervantes , commonly known as "El Mencho," announced Sunday, Feb. 23, triggered "27 cowardly attacks against authorities in Jalisco," Mexican Security Minister Omar Garcia Harfuch told reporters on Monday, adding that 30 cartel operatives were killed as well as one bystander. At least 70 people were arrested in seven states. The U.S. State Department on Feb. 23 widened a security warning advising Americans in several Mexican states to "shelter in place" until further notice, as Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo said "tranquility" had been restored and President Donald Trump urged her government to "step up their effort on Cartels and Drugs!" The State Department later, relaxed its warning for certain areas. 'El Mencho' killed in Mexico: Who was the notorious cartel leader? President Trump urged the Mexican government to "step up their effort on Cartels and Drugs!" after Nemesio RubeÃÅn Oseguera Cervantes, known as "El Mencho," was killed on Sunday. Mexico's president said cartel roadblocks had been cleared from Mexico's highways and that flights would resume in a few days. The State Department says it had "fielded hundreds of calls" from travelers in Mexico with "most pertaining to flight cancellations." 7:33 pm ET February 23, 2026 Share this update Is it safe to travel to Mexico right now? Eve Chen Travelers with imminent plans to vacation in Mexico may want to pause, Mike Ballard, director of intelligence at security firm Global Guardian, told USA TODAY. While resort areas and hotels have been "relatively spared from the impact," he said, people should reconsider their travel plans to Puerto Vallarta or Cancun in the next 48 hours. "We don‚Äôt know exactly how this is going to continue to play out. It could get worse, it could get better," Ballard said. Jason Hanson, former CIA officer and author of ‚ÄúSpy Secrets That Can Save Your Life,‚Äù put it more bluntly: ‚ÄúDo not go to Mexico.‚Äù ‚ÄúI do a lot of security consulting, a lot of travel, and I‚Äôve told people this for the last decade: Do not go to Mexico,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt is way too volatile, way too dangerous. ‚Ä¶ Your life is too precious. Your security‚Äôs too precious. There‚Äôs a million other beautiful places in this world.‚Äù 7:11 pm ET February 23, 2026 Share this update Violence in Mexico could last for days Josh Meyer The public display of violence in Mexico following the slaying of drug lord Nemesio RubeÃÅn Oseguera Cervantes could continue for a few days or weeks, given his stature within the Jalisco New Generation Cartel and the group's extraordinary military-style capabilities, veteran cartel watchers tell USA TODAY. The cartel produced a similar nationwide show of force in 2015, even using a rocket-propelled grenade to shoot down a Mexican army helicopter, after the Mexican military tried to capture Oseguera Cervantes, more commonly known as "El Mencho." ‚ÄúIf past is prologue, what we've seen is that there will be at least a week, maybe more, of these sort of violent reprisals by the cartels. And then things will turn inward,‚Äù Anthony Placido, former head of intelligence for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, told USA TODAY. 6:50 pm ET February 23, 2026 Share this update Mexico deploys 2,000 additional troops to region Michael Loria Authorities in Mexico on Monday deployed an additional 2,000 soldiers to the western part of Jalisco, the Mexican state where most of the fighting is happening. Contributing by Reuters 6:01 pm ET February 23, 2026 Share this update Most airports in Mexico return to normal operations Francesca Chambers Most airports in Mexico are now operating normally, the State Department said on Monday evening as it narrowed its shelter in place advisory for U.S. citizens. U.S. citizens in Puerto Vallarta and the surrounding areas in Jalisco and Nayarit are still being encouraged to shelter in place "due to road blockages and criminal activity related" to the Mexican military raid on Feb. 22. However, the State Department said multiple airlines were operating from Guadalajara and from Puerto Vallarta as of this afternoon. "Confirm that your flight is on track for departure from Guadalajara or Puerto Vallarta before you depart for the airport," it said. 5:37 pm ET February 23, 2026 Share this update US government fields 'hundreds' of calls from stranded travelers Francesca Chambers The State Department says it "has fielded hundreds of calls" from travelers in Mexico with "most pertaining to flight cancellations." The call center is operating 24/7, the State Department said. Americans traveling abroad who need assistance can call +1-202-501-4444 from outside the United States or dial +1-888-407-4747 from the United States or Canada. The U.S. government is also encouraging Americans traveling abroad to enroll in the Smart Traveler Enrollment Program to receive updates about health, weather, safety, and security at their destinations.
